awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Deeply Integrated Physics-Based and Data-Driven Approach for Effective Resilience Management of the Power Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will develop a novel, deeply integrated physics-based data-driven approach to assess and enhance the resilience of power transmission systems impacted by climatic extremes. The US electricity infrastructure is increasingly prone to climatic risks that cause wide-spread and sustained outages, costing billions of dollars annually. While natural hazard-induced failures in the transmission grid lead to large-scale and costly impacts, the existing transmission expansion planning models largely neglect resilience consideration of the network facing natural hazards. The purely data-driven approaches prevalent in resilience analytics of power distribution systems, however, are not applicable to transmission systems due to relative scarcity of data. A unilateral reliance on physics-based models is not feasible either due to their extreme computational costs, limiting their ability to scale up to the network level. This NSF grant seeks to address this fundamental gap via deep integration of physics-based and data driven methods. The outcome of this research is expected to help key decision-makers for the transmission infrastructure to characterize resilience under various uncertain future scenarios and identify optimal adaptation or mitigation strategies. The research program is complemented with educating the next generation of scholars in modeling hazards and infrastructure resilience through an interdisciplinary, research-integrated educational program, a strong commitment to increased diversity in student training and broad dissemination of the results.

The research approach is grounded in the latest developments in big data analytics as well as physics-based analysis of structural failures. The physics-guided, data-centric and multiscale framework allows for scalable assessment of network resilience and identification of optimal investment decisions under climate uncertainty. Using the state-of-the-art machine learning and computer vision, the project will generate new publicly accessible data on transmission network topology as well as hazards’ impacts to facilitate further research in transmission resilience planning within the scientific community. Novel limit state functions for failure quantification of transmission networks will be established and a scalable approach to uncertainty quantification of structural systems will be developed. The multiscale approach to modeling uncertain processes will effectively fuse data on transmission systems with computational models of the infrastructure. The developed methodologies and data will shed new lights on the vulnerability of the transmission system under future hazard scenarios, and enable assessing the impact of investment decisions on transmission system resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This research project significantly advanced the field of power grid resilience by developing novel physics-based and data-driven approaches. Specifically, it focused on modeling the resilience of the transmission grid during extreme climate events by creating a high-fidelity model grounded in infrastructure physics and complemented by data-driven approaches. A major accomplishment was the generation of a detailed and accurate transmission network topology, leveraging large-scale, publicly available, unstructured data sources. The project also created a comprehensive repository of climate impact data, addressing a critical gap in available data and enabling more informed research and decision-making.

The project made significant contributions to the field of computer vision applied to infrastructure systems, advancing techniques in object detection and data augmentation while exploring novel model architectures. By making the project's code and datasets open-source, the researchers facilitated collaboration and reproducibility within the research community, further enhancing the project's impact.

The project's impact extends beyond the principal discipline of civil engineering, with potential applications in other engineering and infrastructure management domains. Furthermore, it contributed significantly to human resource development by training graduate and undergraduate students in advanced areas like reliability analysis, optimization, machine learning, and computer vision. These students gained valuable hands-on experience and interdisciplinary collaboration skills, enriching their educational experiences and preparing them for future research or professional careers. The project's findings have been disseminated through publications, conference presentations, and invited talks, contributing to the broader scientific community.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2025
Modified by: Roshanak Nateghi
